Title: 10+ Guidelines for Better Tables in R
Description: This blog post takes table-making guidelines laid out by data visualization expert Jon Schwabish and shows how they can be achieved using the gt package.

Title: A Scientist's Guide to R: Step 1. Getting Data into R
Description: This article will teach you how to install packages that you can use to import CSV, Excel spreadsheets, and other data into R.

Title: A Scientist's Guide to R: Step 2.1. Data Transformation - Part 1
Description: This article runs through some key functions from the dplyr package for wrangling data.

Title: A Scientist's Guide to R: Step 2.2 - Joining Data with dplyr
Description: The dplyr package has a wide range of functions for joining data. This article walks through them.

Title: A Scientist's Guide to R: Step 2.3 - string manipulation and regex
Description: Covers some of the core functions of the stringr package and has a section on regular expressions for pattern matching.

Title: A Scientist's Guide to R: Step 2.4 - forcats for factors
Description: Factors are how R deals with categorical data with a known number of options. This article will help you understand how factors work.

Title: A Scientist's Guide to R: Step 2.5 - dates & times
Description: Working with dates and times in R can be challenging. This article shows you how to use the lubridate package to work with dates and times.

Title: A Twitter bot with {rtweet} and GitHub Actions
Description: This blog post walks through the process of creating a Twitter bot that posts satellite images of London using the rtweet package and GitHub Actions.

Title: Data Cleaning Flipbook
Description: This flipbook walks through several examples of messy data and shows how to clean them with R.

Title: Data Visualization: A Practical Introduction
Description: This book demonstrates how to create high-quality data visualization in R. Complete with code samples, it's a great resource to improve your visualizations.

Title: Data wrangling for spatial analysis: R Workshop
Description: Materials from a 2020 workshop on spatial analysis in R.

Title: Deep dive intro dplyr
Description: This tutorial is for anyone interested in learning the basics of the dplyr package. We'll be focusing on data exploration and manipulation, building off of the examples in the dplyr package documentation using the Palmer Penguins dataset.

Title: Drawing Anything with ggplot2
Description: This two-part workshop is a deep dive on what you can do with ggplot2.

Title: Functions and Themes for gt tables
Description: This blog post shows how to make nice tables using the gt package.

Title: Geocomputation with R
Description: Geocomputation with R is "a book on geographic data analysis, visualization and modeling." An in-depth yet approachable book, it is a great place to start (and a great reference) for those looking to learn about making maps in R.

Title: geofacet
Description: geofacet enables you to make small multiple plots laid out in grids that are designed to represent the shapes of geographic areas (e.g. states in the United States).

Title: gt Workshop 2020!
Description: Materials from a 2020 workshop about the gt R package.

Title: Interactive web-based data visualization with R, plotly, and shiny
Description: This book provides an overview of the plotly package and has chapters that lay out how to make a wide range of graphs using it.

Title: Learning tidyselect
Description: There are a number of helper functions for selecting columns (e.g. contains()). This tutorial shows you how to use them to select and manipulate variables.

Title: Mapping ggplot geoms and aesthetic properties
Description: In ggplot, each geom uses certain aesthetic properties. This blog post is a cheatsheet to help you remember which geoms work with which aesthetic properties.

Title: Personal Art Map with R
Description: This blog post shows how to use the ggplot2 and sf packages to make a beautiful map.

Title: R for Data Science
Description: Considered the "bible" of the tidyverse approach, this book has chapters on all of the fundamental skills you need to work with R.

Title: R for Data Science, Chapter 11: Data Import
Description: This chapter of R for Data Science teaches you how to import CSV and other rectangular data into R.

Title: R for Data Science, Chapter 16: Dates and Times
Description: This chapter of R for Data Science shows how to work with dates and times in R using the lubridate package.

Title: R Graph Gallery
Description: This website is a collection of visualization types, complete with R code that shows how to make them.

Title: R Graphics Cookbook
Description: This book has recipes that show how to do a variety of tasks in ggplot.

Title: Reactable Tutorial
Description: This tutorial walks through several features of the reactable package for making interactive tables.

Title: Rendering your README with GitHub Actions
Description: Learn how to automate generate a README on your GitHub repository using GitHub Actions.
Related Resource: usethis,A Twitter bot with {rtweet} and GitHub Actions

Title: RStudio Cloud Primers: Visualize Data
Description: These primers explain the basics of visualizing data in R.

Title: Spreadsheet workflows in R
Description: This blog post shows some equivalents between workflows in R and Excel.

Title: Take A Sad Plot & Make It Better: A Case Study with R and ggplot2
Description: This presentation provides a case study of how to improve the quality of a plot.

Title: The ggplot flipbook
Description: This flipbook walks through plots created in ggplot step by step so you can learn how to make your own plots.

Title: The Glamour of Graphics
Description: This presentation at 2020 rstudio::conf shows how you can use ggplot to make high-quality visualizations.

Title: tidy data
Description: This Twitter thread explains the concept of tidy data with clear descriptions and illustrations.

Title: Tidy Data Vignette
Description: This article lays out the principles of tidy data and shows how you can use the tidyr package to get your data into this format.

Title: usethis workflow for package development
Description: This blog post is an overview of how the usethis package can help you to create your own R package.

Title: What is a tidyverse-centric approach?
Description: This blog post lays out what a tidyverse-centric approach to R is, and why you might consider using it in your own code.

Title: What is Takes to Tidy Census Data
Description: This walkthrough provides an example of cleaning Census data to demonstrate principles of tidy data.

Title: Working with categorical data in R without losing your mind
Description: Categorical data, called “factor” data in R, presents unique challenges in data wrangling. R users often look down at tools like Excel for automatically coercing variables to incorrect datatypes, but factor data in R can produce very similar issues. The stringsAsFactors=HELLNO movement and standard Tidyverse defaults have moved us away from the use of factors, but they are sometimes still necessary for analysis. This talk will outline common problems arising from categorical variable transformations in R, and show strategies to avoid them, using both base R and the Tidyverse (particularly, dplyr and forcats functions).

Title: Wrangling categorical data in R
Description: Data wrangling is a critical foundation of data science, and wrangling of categorical data is an important component of this process. However, categorical data can introduce unique issues in data wrangling, particularly in real-world settings with collaborators and periodically-updated dynamic data. This paper discusses common problems arising from categorical variable transformations in R, demonstrates the use of factors, and suggests approaches to address data wrangling challenges. For each problem, we present at least two strategies for management, one in base R and the other from the ‘tidyverse.’ We consider several motivating examples, suggest defensive coding strategies, and outline principles for data wrangling to help ensure data quality and sound analysis.

Title: broom
Description: The broom packages enables you to take output from statistical models and convert it into tidy tibbles. Practically speaking, this means you can easily access elements of the output (e.g. pull out p-values to include in text in an RMarkdown document).

Title: colorblindcheck
Description: colorblindcheck is a package designed to help you decide if your color palette is colorblind friendly.

Title: colorblindr
Description: This package allows you to simulate common forms of colorblindness in order to see how your plots made with ggplot2 appear to those who are color blind.

Title: covdata
Description: covdata is a data package for R that collects and bundles datasets related to the COVID-19 pandemic from a variety of sources.

Title: cowplot
Description: The cowplot package provides various features that help with creating publication-quality figures, such as a set of themes, functions to align plots and arrange them into complex compound figures, and functions that make it easy to annotate plots and or mix plots with images.

Title: dplyr
Description: dplyr is a grammar of data manipulation, providing a consistent set of verbs that help you solve the most common data manipulation challenges. It is one of the core tidyverse packges.

Title: forcats
Description: R uses factors to handle categorical variables, variables that have a fixed and known set of possible values. Factors are also helpful for reordering character vectors to improve display. The goal of the forcats package is to provide a suite of tools that solve common problems with factors, including changing the order of levels or the values. Some examples include:

Title: geogrid
Description: The geogrid packages enables you to "turn geospatial polygons like states, counties or local authorities into regular or hexagonal grids automatically."

Title: ggittext
Description: This package helps you fit text added to plots within boxes.

Title: ggplot2
Description: ggplot2 is the ubiquitous package behind a huge amount of high-quality data visualization.
Creator(s): Kohske Takahashi,Claus Wilke,Dewey Dunnington,Hiroaki Yutani,Hadley Wickham,Winston Chang,Lionel Henry,Thomas Lin Pedersen,Kara Woo

Title: ggspatial
Description: ggspatial provides additional functionality to maps created with ggplot2. For example, it has a function to add a scalebar to help users measure distances in maps.

Title: ggtext
Description: The ggtext package allows you to style text elements of plots. You can use it to add multiple colors to titles, subtitles, captions, etc.

Title: gt
Description: The gt package aims to create a grammar of tables (similar to the grammar of graphics that underlies ggplot2) and use this to help users create attractive tables that communicate effectively.
Related Resource: Functions and Themes for gt tables,10+ Guidelines for Better Tables in R

Title: haven
Description: haven enables R to read and write various data formats used by other statistical packages, including SPSS, SAS, Stata, and more.

Title: jsonlite
Description: jsonlite is a package designed to make it easier to work with JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) data. This type of data is common when working with APIs (application programming interfaces).

Title: leaflet
Description: The leaflet package provides an interface to the popular javascript library of the same name that enables you to make interactive maps.

Title: lubridate
Description: lubridate is a tidyverse-friendly package to simplify the process of working with dates and times.
Related Resource: "R for Data Science, Chapter 16: Dates and Times"

Title: mapdeck
Description: mapdeck is a package for making interactive maps.

Title: patchwork
Description: The patchwork package enables you to combine multiple plots into a single graphic.

Title: plotly
Description: The plotly package enables you to make interactive visualizations. You can either generate figures in ggplot and then add interactivity or use other functions from the package to make interactive figures directly.
Related Resource: "Interactive web-based data visualization with R, plotly, and shiny"

Title: purrr
Description: The purrr package is focused on iteration. You can use it to do things like read in multiple sheets from an Excel spreadsheet into a single data frame, knit an RMarkdown to multiple reports, etc.

Title: qualtRics
Description: This package allows you to import Qualtrics survey data directly into R using the Qualtrics API.

Title: QualtricsInR
Description: This package allows you to use the Qualtrics API to manipulate survey objects and responses, as well as general survey and account administration functions.

Title: raster
Description: The raster package has functions for creating, reading, manipulating, and writing raster data.

Title: reactable
Description: The reactable package makes interactive data tables for R, based on the React Table library and made with reactR.

Title: readr
Description: readr is a package designed "to provide a fast and friendly way to read rectangular data (like csv, tsv, and fwf)."
Related Resource: "R for Data Science, Chapter 11: Data Import"

Title: readxl
Description: The readxl package simplifies the process of importing Excel files into R.

Title: rtweet
Description: rtweet lets you access data from Twitter in order to analyze it in R.

Title: rvest
Description: rvest helps you scrape information from web pages.

Title: sf
Description: The sf package provides tools for working with simple features geospatial data.

Title: snapbox
Description: Add static basemaps from mapbox to maps made with ggplot2.

Title: stringr
Description: "The stringr package provide a cohesive set of functions designed to make working with strings as easy as possible."

Title: stringr.plus
Description: This package provides a few additional functions to supplement those in the string package. They include str_extract_before(), str_extract_after(), and others.

Title: tidycensus
Description: The tidycensus package enables you to get data directly from the United States Census Bureau into R.

Title: tidykids
Description: The not-for-profit organization the Urban Institute created an incredible dataset on State-by-State Spending on Kids that is available here. This data package provides this dataset through R. It is formatted as tidy data to facilitate analysis within the tidyverse suite of R packages.

Title: tidyr
Description: The tidyr package is designed to help you get data into tidy format. With functions to go from wide data to long data, deal with missing values, and more, it provides a toolkit to ensure your data follows tidy principles.

Title: tidyverse
Description: The tidyverse is a collection of packages, all designed to work together. It is also an approach to coding that tends to be friendly to newcomers (but is powerful and used by experienced folks as well!).

Title: tigris
Description: "tigris is an R package that allows users to directly download and use TIGER/Line shapefiles from the US Census Bureau."

Title: tilemaps
Description: This package is designed to take a map and turn it into equally-spaced tile maps.

Title: tmap
Description: tmap is package designed to help you quickly make static and interactive maps.

Title: usethis
Description: usethis is very meta: it's an R package design to help you make your own R package.

Title: zipcodeR
Description: zipcodeR is an R library that makes working with ZIP codes in R easier. It provides data on all U.S. ZIP codes using multiple open data sources, making it easier for social science researchers and data scientists to work with ZIP code-level data in projects.

Title: ggplot2: elegant graphics for data analysis
Description: This book is designed to "help you understand the details of the underlying theory" of the ggplot2 package and "[give] you the power to tailor any plot specifically to your needs."

Title: R as GIS, Part 1
Description: This article walks through some of the basics of using R as a GIS tool.

Title: Date Night: using lubridate to work with dates in R
Description: This presentation gives some examples of how the lubridate package can help you work with dates. Also see the accompanying slides.

Title: A ggplot2 Tutorial for Beautiful Plotting in R
Description: An extremely in-depth blog post demonstrating how to make tweaks large and small to plots made in ggplot.

Title: savonliquide
Description: savonliquide is a tiny package that allows you to generate a report from the Contrast Checker API. The report will display a contrast ratio among other useful information that will judge the accessibility level of your color contrast. savonliquide can be used to evaluate color contrast accessibility for plots, RMarkdown documents, Shiny Apps and even for the RStudio IDE theme (for teaching situations).

Title: breakerofchains
Description: This package enables you to see output at various points in your pipeline (%>%).

Title: tidylog
Description: Tidylog provides feedback about dplyr and tidyr operations. It provides wrapper functions for the most common functions, such as filter, mutate, select, and group_by, and provides detailed output for joins.

Title: ggsteam
Description: ggsteam is a package to make steamplots using ggplot2.

Title: Importing Multiple Files Quickly and Efficiently
Description: This blog post shows how to import multiple CSV files with a few lines of code using several different packages.

Title: data.table
Description: data.table is a package for data importing and wrangling. It has an emphasis on speed when working with large datasets.

Title: vroom
Description: vroom is a package designed to import large data fast.

Title: Leveraging labelled data in R
Description: An article explaining how to work with SPSS, SAS, and Stata datasets with the haven, labelled, and sjlabelled packages.

Title: sjlabelled
Description: This package deals with reading and writing data between other statistical packages (like ‘SPSS’) and R, based on the haven and foreign packages. It includes functions to make working with labelled data easier, including easy ways to get, set or change value and variable label attributes, to convert labelled vectors into factors or numeric (and vice versa), or to deal with multiple declared missing values.

Title: labelled
Description: This package is built on the new classes haven_labelled and haven_labelled_spss introduced by haven package to handle labelled variables imported from SPSS, Stata and SAS. The labelled package propose several functions to manipulate such vectors and their metadata: variable labels, value labels and user-defined missing values.

Title: flair
Description: The goal of flair is to is to provide tools for formatting R code in knitted R Markdown files.

Title: How to Make Slides in R Using xaringan
Description: An overview of the xaringan package.

Title: Meet xaringan: making slides in RMarkdown
Description: A presentation from the 2019 rstudio::conf about the xaringan package.

Title: xaringanthemer
Description: A package to help you give your xaringan slides some style without (much) CSS.

Title: xaringancolor
Description: A package to help you seamlessly use colors across text, code, and equations in #xaringan slides.

Title: xaringanExtra
Description: Billed as a "playground of extensions for xaringan," this package allows you to add animations, a tile view to show all of your slides, the ability to add a logo, and much more.

Title: xaringanBuilder
Description: A package to easily export your xaringan slides to html, PDF, GIF, PPTX, and PNG formats.

Title: Microsoft365R
Description: A package to work with files stored on Microsoft365 services, including SharePoint Online and OneDrive.

Title: gluedown
Description: The goal of gluedown is to ease the transition from R’s powerful vectors to formatted markdown text. Practically speaking, this means you can do things like convert vectors into bulleted lists in documents knitted from RMarkdown.

Title: Introduction to the Field of Statistics (and R Statistical Software)
Description: This course is an "introduction to the discipline of statistics, including the development of the discipline, professional ethics, data visualization and the role of statistics in the scientific enterprise."

Title: RMarkdown
Description: RMarkdown is a tool to help you go from data import to final report, all without leaving R.
Creator(s): JJ Allaire,Yihui Xie,Jonathan McPherson,Javier Luraschi,Kevin Ushey,Hadley Wickham,Aron Atkins,Joe Cheng,Winston Chang, Richard Iannone

Title: R’s Killer Feature: RMarkdown
Description: This blog post walks through what RMarkdown is and why it's valuable.

Title: R-Bootcamp
Description: The R-Bootcamp is a gentle and gradual introduction to manipulating and visualizing data in R using the `tidyverse` suite of packages. It is meant for incoming Oregon Health and Science University Bioinformatics and Computational Biomedicine Majors but is appropriate for any beginners wanting to learn elementary data manipulation in R.

Title: Data Science for the Biomedical Sciences
Description: Materials for a workshop geared toward those in biomedical sciences.

Title: Stat545
Description:
The materials for Stat545 are design to help you learn how to:
  • explore, groom, visualize, and analyze data,
  • make all of that reproducible, reusable, and shareable,
  • using R.
This materials cover everything that comes up during data analysis except for statistical modelling and inference.
Category: Data Visualization,Data Wrangling,Data Import,Tidy Data,Git,Package Development

Title: Getting more out of dplyr
Description: This 2018 talk goes over some of the less used functions from dplyr.

Title: ViewPipeSteps
Description: This RStudio add-in enables you to see results of your pipeline at each step.

Title: Pivoting tidily
Description: This blog post provides an overview of the pivot functions — pivot_longer() and pivot_wider() — from the tidyr package.

Title: Data Wrangling with dplyr and tidyr
Description: This lesson from a course on R for social scientists from The Carpentries covers working with data using dplyr and tidyr.

Title: RStudio Cloud Primer: Work with Data
Description: A tutorial to "learn the most important data handling skills in R: how to extract values from a table, subset tables, calculate summary statistics, and derive new variables."

Title: RStudio Cloud Primer: Tidy Your Data
Description: A tutorial to "unlock the tidyverse by learning how to make and use tidy data, the data format designed for R."

Title: RStudio Cloud Primer: Visualize Your Data
Description: A tutorial to help you "learn how to use ggplot2 to make any type of plot with your data. Then learn the best ways to visualize patterns within values and relationships between variables."

Title: RStudio Cloud Primer: Iterate
Description: A tutorial to help you "master a core programming paradigm with the purrr package: for each ____ do ____."

Title: RStudio Cloud Primer: Functions
Description: A tutorial that will "teach you how to write and use your own reusable functions."

Title: Using the tidyverse with Databases
Description: The first in a three-part series of connecting to databases from R.

Title: dbplyr
Description: "dbplyr is the database backend for dplyr. It allows you to use remote database tables as if they are in-memory data frames by automatically converting dplyr code into SQL."

Title: RSQLite
Description: This package "embeds the SQLite database engine in R, providing a DBI-compliant interface. SQLite is a public-domain, single-user, very light-weight database engine that implements a decent subset of the SQL 92 standard, including the core table creation, updating, insertion, and selection operations, plus transaction management."

Title: DBI
Description: The DBI package helps connecting R to database management systems (DBMS). DBI separates the connectivity to the DBMS into a “front-end” and a “back-end.”

Title: R for Data Science: Chapter 19: Functions
Description: This chapter from R for Data Science goes over how functions work, and how to create your own.

Title: Stat545: Chapters 18-20: Write your own functions
Description: These chapters cover how functions work, and how to write your own.

Title: How to Make Functions in R
Description: This post, complete with a video, shows how to make your own functions.
